Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2010 10:45PM - edited Apr 14, 2010 10:46PM by AMP47 My Â oncotype dx score was 17 Â the high end of the low recurrence. with a 10 per cent chance of distant recurrence. Â  My oncologist, surgeon and radiologist agreed no chemo. Â There was only a 3 per cent benefit for me which did not out weight the negative long term effects of chemo. There are many studies discussing the efficacy of this test. Â Go to the Oncotype dx website there is alot of information available about the test My oncologist said this is only the beginning of the new wave in breast cancer treatment: personalised treatment for each patient. Â By studying the biology of the tumour, doctors can make more effective treatment plans for their patients. Â Traditional methods throw all of us over 1 cm into a chemo pool: a pool that over treated many women who did not benefit from chemo and suffered the long lasting effects of chemo when they did not have to. Â Â

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 10:09AM AMP47 wrote: Sassa I don't get on line often, but when I read your posted felt I needed to comment. Â  Although, the other ladies on this thread have absolutely hit on many points that under minds your argument of what Â constitutes a "responsible adult" a few points were missed. Â  First, this man is a responsible adult-he has a job. Â That constitute a responsible person who doesn't abuse the system. Unless you have another set of criteria that determines whether a person is responsible. Â Doesn't sound like you do, though. Â  You discuss your daughter purchasing a private policy as responsible behavior. Â So, I am assuming, that since this man has benefits that include health coverage, which includes his wife, he is considered to be responsible? Â Both are responsible adults. Â  Can't have it both ways you are either pregnant or your not. Â  Second, his wife gets to stay home and not work if she desires-we live in America and we get to make that choice for our family. The last time I checked being a responsible person also is associated with being a responsible partner in sharing the duties of an economic partnership-marriage. He works she stays home. Â Sounds OK to me. Â  Third, non profit companies that organize to help people such as this man and his wife, spend their money on staff, benefits and other items instead of helping the people they organized to help. Â Now that is being a irresponsible: organization staffed with allot of adults along for the ride. Taxes paid by all of us responsible adults ultimately flow through the grant process Â to these organizations. Â  Ummmm we pay taxes, the organization get Â funds through grant application and distribution from either the feds or their state government who collects taxes; Â the organization makes a promise, in their mission statement, to take care of people who need help if the government gives them money; Â their staffs are taken care enjoy great health benefits, salaries and many perks; Â but somehow the organization get out of helping the group they organized to help-now that sounds a little irresponsible to me. Â What do you think? Â  Â Fourth, I am sure this man has p aid his fair share of taxes over the years that support the systems that support illegal aliens. Â As citizen, don't you think the people paying the taxes should be entitled to the same benefits that illigal aliens are provided? Â As a tax payer and small business owner-I DO. Â  Sure, you preface your argument to be politically correct that illegal aliens should not be given benefit, where have you been living in a cave? Â  NEWSFLASH-they get many services that we citizens can not obtain and this man is a "case in point". Oh, and those organizations that forgot what they organized for, to helpÂ American citizens, well, they extend help to this disparaged part of our populationÂ by helping them. Â Why because it is politically correct and great publicity to help organizations secure future funding from the govenment. Â Why on earth would they help the very person who works to pay tax that funds their organization???? Â Don't you think that is a little on the irresponsible on a very large scale?Â  Finally, I notice that you have invited all of us to, as you say, "Flame Away" laced in an undertone of cruel, unsympathetic lack of concern for your fellow human being. Â Are you looking to do battle over the life of a sister on this web site? Â This site is a support site dealing with life and death issues not a site for people who want to spin the facts of the matter and then invite debate. Â Go to another site and debate away. Â Or maybe you are looking to form your own "death panel" by making decision on who and who can not get medical help from the very organizations that he supports through his tax bill every year. Â  One last point, you obviously do not understand why the cost of insurance is beyond most peoples reach the insurance companies have very strong representation in congress to keep things the way they are. Â This health bill just paved their way to financial heaven. Â Not only are the doctors Â going be receiving less money, 21% to exact, Â private health insurance premiums are going up not down. Â Â How do I know this-my private health insurance just took a steep increase. Â Why, because of the new health bill provisions. Â Gee, I wonder how many people who were employed for years, now unemployed, will be able to continue to pay the new premiums. Â Darn those irresponsible people who can not afford being raped by the insurance company any more. Â Shame on them Â  The insurance companies will add that to their bottom line the reduction in payment to physicians and the higher cost of customers premiums. Â Not only do our doctors get screwed we are going to get screwed in the process. Â Now that everyone will be fined for not having insurance more profits for the insurance company. Â Eventually, your daughter will not be able to afford insurance, due to the rise in cost especially on a income of meger resource. Â Will you then Â label her irresponsible? Â Or will you step down from your perch and take a hard look at the system that allow the insurance companies to manipulate Â the health care system?Â  Maybe you should advocate for the insurance companies Â and support their criteria which is screw the doctors and screw the patient and support the people who can continue to pay high premiums that feed the bottom line of the insurance company-sounds like legal thievery to me rooted in elitism. Â  Â Â  Are you mean spirited sure sounds like it. Â  Would it do any good to tell you that probably not. Â But, your statement is so egregious that comment is necessary. Â

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 12:09AM AMP47 wrote: Marie makes some very important and solid statements. Â My oncology nurse agrees with her statements referring to a possible wrong interpretation. Â For example my grade was originally 2 but after redoing the process, I was a grade 1 with a mitotic rate of 1, also. Â  To be human is to error. Â Its is our responsibility to make sure our information is correct. For two years I have read many articles, university studies, papers about the concordance between Ki67 and grade. Â Also, I have accessed several doctors and "popped" the question to them. Â Since the Ki67 was not part of my pathology report, I began to worry when reading alot of the post on this site with Ki67 information pathology report.Â  I have yet to read an article that does not discuss the concordance with ki67 and grade being: low Ki67 = low tumour grade. Â The reason my report does not include Ki67 is because of newer techniques for determining proliferation rate is now being used. Â  My oncologist said the mitotic rate is the most important number for me which was 1. Â Also, they do not use Ki67 as a measure of survival anymore, or a prognostic factor for overall survival, at least in my area. The Internet is full of medical journals, articles and studies dealing with the question. Â Hope this helps. Â Good luck in your research. Â Â

Â I will be meeting with my favorite doctor of my team the radiologist, who is Chief of Radiology at Providence Hospital in Oregon to help me understand why it was important for a call back today then ended up being nothing. Â  Â I did read that on a spot compression that a suspicious spot on a mammogram would spread out if benign and if it retains its shape there is a possibility of malignancy. Maybe that is why it was nothing today?? Â  So. Â Good news just wanted to share with everyone.l Â Thanks to Â everyone who posted their support. Prayers are so important and just talking with other women on this site makes the journey more bearable Â  AMP

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 02:53PM AMP47 wrote: jlynnbain1031 - Ki-67 is a measurement of how fast a cell copies its DNA and divides. Â It is also thought to be associated with high grade: you have grade 2, inbetween very well behaved cells and cells on the fast track. Â As far as the unfavorable and range 18% -adverse prognosis may be referring to the Ki-67 index. Â  When I ask my oncologist, radiologist and nurse navigator what the Ki-67 was and why my disease was not tested for the Ki-67. Â Both said it was something they tested for in prior years but do not much anymore. Â Reason being they do not use it as a prognostic factor to survival. Â  To get a sound answer to your question, Â  go to John Hopkins Ask and Expert and pose the question to Lilly a nurse navigator. Â  Â She will answer your question either that day or within a day. Â Plus you can look through questions that have Â already been ask and an answered by Lilly. Â You will find this site very, very informative. Lilly is a breast cancer survivor-twice. Â She has been there, done that and now helps women with questions they have about their diagnosis. Â You can private message me if you have trouble getting to John Hopkins site. Â Cyber hugs to you. Â AMP

Â  I am 16 months from my lumpectomy and can not feel what ever the radiologist sees on the screen?Â Â Â Also, he only sees it on one view not both??Â  Any of you ladies had a call back due to an ovoid shaped nodule for a spot compression.Â  If so, IÂ would like to hear from you.Â  Very nervous about this call back.Â  First call back for me. Thanks for answering my question.Â  AMPÂ  Â  Dx 1/15/2009, IDC, Left, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (IHC) Surgery 2/14/2009 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2019 01:15AM - edited Mar 11, 2019 01:24AM by AMP47 Sunset - sooo glad to see that was a typo! I was diagnois recently with the original diagnois as in 2009 for a 4mm rib bone met through a CT scan two weeks ago. Since that day my life has been days of bad frieghtening news/reports. After 11 years of cancer free worry- now this. I am on a crash course on verbiage, euphanizms, medication and survival time Statistics. Very glad this site is here for all of us dealing with nasty ever evolving disease. Woman like your self help woman like me get a grip on what happens when it comes back, what medicines will be available the outcome of the medicines used. In your case 8 years later. You have managed your condition for a long time. When did you know when you had possibly years versus months? What does NED and MO mean? Look forward to your responses. Thanks for your help- I am pretty unsettled right now - trying to keep it together ðŸ˜” AM

Everything was clear except for the following note on the report. A small focus of activity within the tip of RIGHT lobe of liver, whether this presents an early metastic focus or possibly a small hemangioma is uncertain. This is a non-specific finding. CT does show a small area of decreased attenuation which is nonspecific. Consider dedicated MRI examination of liver with contrast” When your met was discovered - was there language similar to the above. Pretty nervouse about the language. Definitly calling doc to set up MRI. Any thoughts?

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2019 01:38AM AMP47 wrote: Hello Mary Jane - thank you for all the information on abbreviations. Also, I was unaware of oligometastatic is a condition for years of survival. That is encouraging news. I have been very sad with many “gloom and doom” sessions during my day. You describe the feeling of this disease return as a “gut punch” accurately. Many many days were as you describe. I had to get an anti-anxiety medication . I have worked on being calm and staying busy which really helps me. I agree with the “forgetter pill” - made me laugh. I will be glad when the MRI is over. My son-in-law is a radiologist and reads my reports and holds my hand and makes recommendations to move things along-very kind supportive man. Hugs Annamari
